Submodules¶

raytracer.cartesian module¶

raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_add(c1, c2)¶

Adds two cartesians together

Parameters:
  • c1 – a cartesian
  • c2 – a cartesian
Returns:

a cartesian, the result of adding c1 and c2
raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_copy(c)¶

Creates a copy of a cartesian

Parameters:c – a cartesian to copy
Returns:a copy of empty_shape
raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_create(x, y, z)¶

Creates a cartesian tuple

Parameters:
  • x – The x part of the co-ordinate
  • y – The y part of the co-ordinate
  • z – The z part of the co-ordinate
Returns:

a tuple representing a cartesian
raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_cross(c1, c2)¶

Calculates the cross product of two cartesians.

Parameters:
  • c1 – a cartesian
  • c2 – a cartesian
Returns:

cross-product of c1 and c2
raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_dot(c1, c2)¶

Calculates the dot product of cartesians c1 and c2 :param c1: a cartesian :param c2: a cartesian :return: the dot product of cartesians c1 and c2

raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_len(c)¶

Calculates the length of given cartesian. Useful for vectors.

c1: a cartesian :return: the length of given c1

raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_normalise(c)¶

Creates a cartesian with a length of 1 from the given cartesian. Useful for Vectors

param c:a cartesian
return:a normalised cartesian
raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_scale(c1, scale)¶

Multiples the cartesian by the scalar value given. Useful for Vectors

Parameters:
  • c1 – a cartesian
  • scale – the value to scale/multiply the c1 by.
Returns:

c1 multiplied by scale
raytracer.cartesian.cartesian_sub(c1, c2)¶

Subtracts cartesian c2 from cartesian c1

Parameters:
  • c1 – a cartesian
  • c2 – a cartesian
Returns:

a cartesian, the result of subtracting c2 from c1
raytracer.cartesian.lineseg2d_ccw(A, B, C)¶

Line intersection code derived from http://bryceboe.com/2006/10/23/line-segment-intersection-algorithm/

raytracer.cartesian.lineseg2d_create(start, end)¶

Creates a lineseg2d tuple

raytracer.cartesian.lineseg2d_intersect(ls1, ls2)¶

Determines if two line segments intersect with each other. (Used for polygon intersection tests).

Line intersection code derived from http://bryceboe.com/2006/10/23/line-segment-intersection-algorithm/

raytracer.cartesian.ray_calc_pt(ray, t)¶

Calculates a point along a ray, returning a cartesian. The vector part of the the ray is scaled by t and added to the start point of the array.

Parameters:
  • ray – a ray tuple
  • t – the position along the ray, proportional to the vector component of the ray.
Returns:

a cartesian, calculated by the expression ray start + (ray vector * t)
raytracer.cartesian.ray_create(start, vector, shadow=False)¶

Creates a ray tuple

Parameters:
  • start – a cartesian point, being the start of the ray
  • vector – a cartesian vector, being the direction of the ray
  • shadow – a boolean, indicating if the ray is being used for shadow detection.
Returns:

a ray tuple
raytracer.cartesian.ray_is_shadow(ray)¶

Determines if the ray is used for shadow detection

Parameters:ray – a ray tuple
Returns:the fourth element from the tuple, being a boolean.
raytracer.cartesian.ray_scale(ray, scale)¶

Multiples the lenth of the ray by the given scale

Parameters:
  • ray – a ray tuple
  • scale – the value to scale the length by
Returns:

a new ray, being the a ray with the same start point as the given ray, and the vector from the given ray but scaled by the given amount
raytracer.cartesian.transform_matrix_mul_cartesian(matrix, cartesian)¶

Multiplies a matrix by a Cartesian, resulting in a transformed cartesian.

Parameters:
  • matrix – a matrix
  • cartesian – a cartesian tuple
Returns:

cartesian

  • c1 – A colour tuple
  • c2 – A colour tuple
Returns:

A couple tuple, the result of adding c1 and c2
raytracer.colour.colour_create(r, g, b)¶

Creates a colour tuple

Parameters:
  • r – The red component of the colour
  • g – The green component of the colour
  • b – The blue component of the colour
Returns:

A tuple: (‘colour’,r,g,b)
raytracer.colour.colour_mul(c1, c2)¶

Multiplies two colour together. One of the colour tuples should have scalar values. Useful for calculating relflected colours.

Parameters:
  • c1 – A colour tuple
  • c2 – A colour tuple
Returns:

c1 multiplied by c2
raytracer.colour.colour_scale(c1, scale)¶

Multiplies a colour by the given scale

Parameters:
  • c1 – A colour
  • scale – A scalar value
Returns:

c1 scaled by the scale parameter

raytracer.light module¶

raytracer.light.light_cone_is_inside(light, point)¶

Tests if a point is inside a cone. The cone is defined as having a base at x=0, y=0, z=0, having a height of 1, and a radius of 1 at that height.

light: The cone light point: A cartesian as a point to test
Returns:Boolean
raytracer.light.light_conelight_create(colour, transform)¶

Creates a tuple for a cone-shaped light

raytracer.light.light_directional_is_inside(light, point)¶

Tests if a point is inside the area of a directional light. This calls the function stored in the directional light tuple for testing inside/outside.

Parameters:
  • light – The directional light
  • point – A cartesian as a point to test
Returns:

Boolean
raytracer.light.light_point_light_create(point, colour)¶

Creates a point light.

Parameters:
  • point – A cartesian point (see cartesian module documentation)
  • colour – A colour (see cartesian module documentation)
Returns:

A tuple of light parameters
raytracer.light.light_tube_is_inside(point)¶

Tests if a point is inside a cone. The cylinder is defined as having a radius of 1, where Y is between 0 and 1.

Parameters:point – A cartesian as a point to test
Returns:Boolean
raytracer.light.light_tubelight_create(colour, transform)¶

Creates a tube/cylinder shaped light

Parameters:
  • light – The cone light
  • point – A cartesian as a point to test
Returns:

a tuple respresenting a directional light

raytracer.lighting_model.lightingmodel_basic_calculate(lighting_model, scene_obj, result)¶

Calculates the colour where a ray intersects with an object.

lightingmodel: a lighting model tuple. :param scene_obj: the Scene object :param result: the intersection test results :return: a tuple of colour information

To do: Implement reflections.

Creates a tuple with data for basic lighting model.

Parameters:
  • ambient_light – The colour of the ambient light to apply
  • max_reflect – the maximum number of recursive reflections to allow

Returns: a lighting model tuple

raytracer.planarshapes module¶

raytracer.planarshapes.shape_disc_create(colour, specular, transform=None)¶

Creates a tuple with the data necessary to render a disc.

Parameters:
  • colour – the colour of the disc.
  • specular – the reflective colour of the disc.
  • transform – the transformation to apply to the disc.
Returns:

a tuple containg data to render a disc
raytracer.planarshapes.shape_disc_intersect(shape, ray)¶

Intersection test function for a disc. An untranslated disc is located at X=0, Y=0, Z=0, sits on the XY plane, and has a radius of 1 in both X and Y.

Parameters:
  • shape – the shape tuple for the disc
  • ray – the ray to perform the intersection test with
Returns:

False if no intersection, or a dictionary of results when there is an intersection.
raytracer.planarshapes.shape_polygon_convert2d(shape, point)¶

Takes a point in 3D space and flattens it without perspective into 2D space. (The 2D points are used for inside/outside tests).

Parameters:
  • shape – the polygon related to the point
  • point – a cartesian point to flatten
Returns:

a tuple with a 2D co-oridnate

  • specular – the reflective colour of the polygon.

the transformation to apply to the polygon.

a tuple containg data to render a polygon

raytracer.planarshapes.shape_rectangle_create(colour, specular, bounds, transform=None)¶

Creates a tuple with the data necessary to render a rectangle. An untransformed rectangle sits on the XY plane, at Z=0, with the minimum and maximum bounds for X and Y set by the bounds parameter.

Parameters:
  • colour – the colour of the rectangle.
  • specular – the reflective colour of the rectangle
  • bounds – a dictionary with the following values ‘top’: the minimum Y value of the rectangle ‘bottom’: the maximum Y value of the rectangle ‘left’: the minimum X value of the rectangle ‘right’: the maximum X value of the rectangle
  • transform – the transformation to apply to the rectangle.
Returns:

a tuple containg data to render a rectangle
raytracer.planarshapes.shape_rectangle_intersect(shape, ray)¶

Intersection test function for a rectangle.

Parameters:
  • shape – the shape tuple for the rectangle
  • ray – the ray to perform the intersection test with
Returns:

False if no intersection, or a dictionary of results when there is an intersection
raytracer.planarshapes.shape_triangle_create(points, colours, reflections=None)¶

Creates a tuple with the data necessary to render a triangle.

colour: the colour of the triangle. specular: the reflective colour of the triangle. points: a list or tuple of three cartesians points, being the vertices ofthe triangle

Parameters:
  • colours –
  • reflections –
Returns:

a tuple containg data to render a triangle
raytracer.planarshapes.shape_triangle_diffuse_colour(shape, intersect_result)¶

Calculate the diffuse colour of a point on a triangle, where different colours have been specified for each vertex (colour shading). If no colour shading is used, the function returns the standard diffuse colour. :param shape: the triangle to get the colour from :param intersection_result: A dictionary of intersection results. This parameter is not used, but kept to match the gnature of other colour functions :return: a colour tuple

raytracer.planarshapes.shape_triangle_intersect(shape, ray)¶

Intersection test function for a triangle.

Parameters:
  • shape – the shape tuple for the triangle
  • ray – the ray to perform the intersection test with
Returns:

False if no intersection, or a dictionary of results when there is an intersection
raytracer.planarshapes.shape_triangle_specular_colour(self, intersect_result)¶

Calculate the specular colour of a point on a triangle, where different colours have been specified for each vertex (colour shading). If no colour shading is used, the function returns the standard specular colour. :param shape: the triangle to get the colour from :param intersection_result: A dictionary of intersection results. This parameter is not used, but kept to match the signature of other colour functions :return: a colour tuple

raytracer.quadraticshapes module¶

raytracer.quadraticshapes.shape_capped_cone_create(colour, specular, topcap={}, bottomcap={}, y_top=None, y_bottom=None, transform=None)¶

Creates a tuple with the necessary data for rendering a capped cone. An untransformed cone is in parallel to the Y axis, having a radius equal to the Y position. The apex of the untransformed cone is at X=0, Y=0, Z=0. Optionally, the minumum and maximum values of Y for the rendered cone can be specified.

Parameters:
  • colour – the colour of the cylinder.
  • specular – the reflective colour of the cylinder.
  • topcap – a dictionary with the following two optional members ‘diffuse_colour’: the diffuse colour for the ‘top’ cap of the cylinder ‘specular_colour’: the specular colour for the ‘top’ cap of the cylinder
  • bottomcap – a dictionary with the following two optional members ‘diffuse_colour’: the diffuse colour for the ‘bottom’ cap of the cylinder ‘specular_colour’: the specular colour for the ‘bottom’ cap of the cylinder
  • y_top – The minimum Y value in an untransformed cone. If this parameter is None, the default of 0 will be used.
  • y_bottom – The maximum Y value in an untransformed cone. If this parameter is None, the default of 1 will be used.
  • transform – the transformation to apply to the cylinder.
Returns:

a tuple with the data needed to render a capped cone.
raytracer.quadraticshapes.shape_capped_cone_diffuse_colour(shape, intersect_result)¶

Returns the diffuse colour for an intersection point with a capped cone. This function is needed because different colours can be specified for cylinder body and both caps.

Parameters:
  • shape – the cone to query
  • intersect_result – a dictionary of intersection results
Returns:

the diffuse colour for the specified intersection
raytracer.quadraticshapes.shape_capped_cone_intersect(shape, ray)¶

Intersection test function for a capped cone.

Parameters:
  • shape – the shape tuple for the capped cylinder
  • ray – the ray to perform the intersection test with
Returns:

False if no intersection, or a dictionary of results when there is an intersection.
To do: Implement optionality for cap intersection test. Thourough checking
for all instances needed.
raytracer.quadraticshapes.shape_capped_cone_specular_colour(shape, intersect_result)¶

Returns the specular colour for an intersection point with a capped cone. This function is needed because specular colours can be specified for cylinder body and both caps.

Parameters:
  • shape – the cone to query
  • intersect_result – a dictionary of intersection results
Returns:

a colour
raytracer.quadraticshapes.shape_capped_cylinder_create(colour, specular, topcap={}, bottomcap={}, transform=None)¶

Creates a capped cylinder tuple.

Parameters:
  • colour – the colour of the cylinder
  • specular – the reflective colour of the cylinder
  • topcap – a dictionary with the following two optional members ‘diffuse_colour’: the diffuse colour for the ‘top’ cap of the cylinder ‘specular_colour’: the specular colour for the ‘top’ cap of the cylinder
  • bottomcap – a dictionary with the following two optional members ‘diffuse_colour’: the diffuse colour for the ‘bottom’ cap of the cylinder ‘specular_colour’: the specular colour for the ‘bottom’ cap of the cylinder
  • transform – the transformation to apply to the cylinder
Returns:

a tuple with data for rendering a capped cylinder

raytracer.quadraticshapes.shape_cone_create(colour, specular, y_top=None, y_bottom=None, transform=None)¶

Creates a tuple with the necessary data for rendering a cone. An untransformed cone is in parallel to the Y axis, having a radius equal to the Y position. The apex of the untransformed cone is at X=0, Y=0, Z=0. Optionally, the minumum and maximum values of Y for the rendered cone can be specified.

Parameters:
  • colour – the colour of the cylinder.
  • specular – the reflective colour of the cylinder.
  • y_top – The minimum Y value in an untransformed cone. If this parameter is None, the default of 0 will be used.
  • y_bottom – The maximum Y value in an untransformed cone. If this parameter is None, the default of 1 will be used.
  • transform – the transformation to apply to the cylinder.
Returns:

a tuple with the data needed to render a cone.
raytracer.quadraticshapes.shape_cone_intersect(shape, ray)¶

Intersection test function for a cone.

Parameters:
  • shape – the shape tuple for the capped cylinder
  • ray – the ray to perform the intersection test with
Returns:

False if no intersection, or a dictionary of results when there is an intersection.

  • point – the point to test

Intersection test function for a sphere. An untranslated sphere is located at X=0, Y=0, Z=0, with a radius of 1.

raytracer.scene module¶

class raytracer.scene.Scene¶

Bases: object

add_light(light, name=None)¶

Add a light to the scene :param light: the light to add :param name: a text handle for the light

add_shape(shape, name=None)¶

Add a shape to the scene :param shape: the shape to add :param name: a text handle for the shape

add_view(view_obj, name=None)¶

Adds a view to the scene. :return: an array of lights :param view_obj: the view to add :param name: a string handle for the view

get_lights()¶

Returns the array of lights in the scene. :return: an array of lights

render(view_name)¶

Renders the scene using the specified view. The output type must be set prior to calling this method. :param view_name: the handle of the view to use :return: the output of the rendered scene, or None if no output type

is set
test_intersect(ray, exclude_shapes=[])¶

Tests intersection of a ray with all the shapes in the scene. :param ray: the ray to test against the shapes :param exclude_shapes: a list of shapes to exclude from the intersection test

raytracer.shape module¶

raytracer.shape.shape_diffuse_colour(shape, intersect_result=None)¶

Returns the diffuse colour for a shape that is stored in the shape tuple. :param shape: a shape :param intersect_result: a dictionary of intersection results. This parameter is not used.

raytracer.shape.shape_empty_shape()¶

“Returns a list with some starting elements necessary for a shape.

Returns:[‘shape’, None, None, None, None, None, shape_diffuse_colour, shape_specular_colour, None, {}]
raytracer.shape.shape_point_inside(shape, cartesian)¶
raytracer.shape.shape_reverse_transform(intersect_result)¶

Transforms the normal from an intersection with a shape into scene-space, if there is a Transformation set for the shape

Parameters:intersect_result – a dictionary of intersection results.
Returns:the dictionary of intersection results, with member ‘normal’ added.
raytracer.shape.shape_set_transform(shape, transform)¶

Sets the transformation for a shape. :param shape: a shape :param transform: a Transformation object

raytracer.shape.shape_specular_colour(shape, intersect_result=None)¶

Returns the specular colour for a shape that is stored in the shape tuple. :param shape: a shape :param intersect_result: a dictionary of intersection results. This parameter is not used.

raytracer.shape.shape_test_intersect(shape, ray)¶

Tests a ray for intersection against a shape. This function transforms the ray into shape-space before calling the shape’s intersection test function.

Parameters:
  • shape – the shape to test against
  • ray – the ray to test
Returns:

a dictionary of intersection results if the ray intersects, else False if the ray does not intersect.

raytracer.transformation module¶

class raytracer.transformation.Transform(options)¶

Bases: object

A class to support matrix transformations of rays and cartesians

inverse_transform(normal, translate=False)¶

Applies inverse transformation to a vector. (Used for normals.)

Parameters:normal – a cartesian to transform
Returns:the transformed vector
matrix()¶

Returns the calculated matrix.

Returns:Matrix object
no_transform()¶

Returns True if the transform would not result in any change to a ray or cartesian, else False

Returns:boolean
options()¶

Returns a dictionary of transformation options.

Returns:dictionary
set_options(options)¶

Sets transformation options.

Parameters:options – a dictionary with the following optional elements:
  • ‘translate’: a dictionary with the following elements:

    o ‘x’: the distance to translate in the X dimension o ‘y’: the distance to translate in the Y dimension o ‘z’: the distance to translate in the Z dimension

  • ‘scale’: a dictionary with the following elements:

    o ‘x’: the amount to scale in the X dimension o ‘y’: the amount to scale in the Y dimension o ‘z’: the amount to scale in the Z dimension

  • ‘rotation’: a dictionary with the following elements:

    o ‘vector’: a cartesian vector to use as an axis to rotate about o ‘angle’: the angle to rotate about the vector, in degrees

transform(ray)¶

Transforms a given ray.

Parameters:ray – a ray to transform.
Returns:the ray, transformed
transform_point(point, inverse=False)¶

Transforms a point. (A point can only be transformed by translation.)

Parameters:
  • point – a cartesian to transform
  • inverse – A boolean. If True the inverse transformation is applied
Returns:

the translated point

raytracer.view module¶

raytracer.view.view_create(scene, eye_z, physical_rectangle, view_rectangle, transform=None, output=None)¶

Creates a view.

param eye_z:The Z-position of the eye point. This should be a negative value.
param physical_rectangle:
 The rectangle of the physical output to draw onto. This is value is a dictionary: ‘left’: the left-hand edge of the physical output to draw onto ‘right’: the right-hand edge of the physical output to draw onto ‘top’: the top edge of the physical output to draw onto ‘bottom’: the bottom edge of the physical output to draw onto
param view_rectangle:
 The rectangle of the logical view to draw at where z=0. This is a dictionary: ‘left’: the left-hand edge ‘right’: the right-hand edge ‘top’: the top edge ‘bottom’: the bottom edge
Parameters:transformation – A transformation to apply to the view(optional)
Returns:A list of view parameters, or None on failure
raytracer.view.view_render(view)¶

Renders a view of a scene.

Parameters:
  • view – The view to render
  • lightingmodel_flags – Flags that affect behaviour of the lighting model
raytracer.view.view_render_pixel(view, physical_x, physical_y)¶

Renders one pixel of a view

Parameters:
  • view – The view to render
  • physical_x – The X co-ordinate of the pixel
  • physical_y – The Y co-ordinate of the pixel
raytracer.view.view_render_pixel_antialias_edge_detect(view, force_antialias=False)¶

Performs edge-detecting antialiasing for the current pixel of a render.

Parameters:
  • view – The view to render
  • force_antialias – Boolean - disregard edge detection and antialias anyhow
Returns:

a colour tuple
raytracer.view.view_render_pixel_antialias_edge_detect_get_surrounding_eight(view)¶

Returns the eight surrounding view co-ordinates for the pixel currently being rendered

Parameters:view – the view
Returns:an array of tuples with view co-ordinates
raytracer.view.view_render_pixel_antialias_grid_pattern(view)¶

Performs non-stochastic antialiasing for the current pixel of a render.

Parameters:view – The view to render
Returns:a colour tuple
raytracer.view.view_render_pixel_antialias_stochastic(view)¶

Performs stochastic antialiasing for the current pixel of a render.

Parameters:view – The view to render
Returns:a colour tuple
raytracer.view.view_render_pixel_no_antialias(view)¶

Performs the current pixel of a render without antialiasing.

Parameters:
  • view – The view to render
  • lightingmodel_flags – Flags that affect behaviour of the lighting model
Returns:

a colour tuple
raytracer.view.view_set_antialias(view, on=False, x=1, y=1, stochastic=False, edge_detect=False, ed_threshold=0.3)¶

Sets the antialias parameters for a view.

Parameters:
  • view – The view to change
  • on – Boolean value dictating to using antialias while rendering or not
  • stochastic – Boolean value dictating use of stochastic/random antialiasing
  • edge_detect – Boolean value dictating use edge detection
  • ed_threshold – a value between one and 0 indicating the difference between pixels necessary for edge-detecting antialiasing
  • x – How many times to divide a pixel on the horizontal axis
  • y – How many times to divide a pixel on the vertical axis
raytracer.view.view_set_lighting_model(view, lightingmodel, options=None)¶

Sets the lighting model for a view

Parameters:
  • view – The view to change
  • lightingmodel – Lighting model to use while rendering the scene
  • options – optional lighting model options dictionary
raytracer.view.view_set_output(view, output)¶

Set or change the transformation for a view.

Parameters:
  • view – The view to change
  • transform – The Transformation to apply
raytracer.view.view_set_transform(view, transform)¶

Set or change the transformation for a view.

Parameters:
  • view – The view to change
  • transform – The Transformation to apply
